infrastructure.cdn: Netlify Edge (backed by AWS / Amazon CloudFront)
infrastructure.whois: Netlify subdomain — WHOIS not applicable (free-tier platform abuse)

tls.issuer: C=US, O=DigiCert Inc, CN=DigiCert Global G2 TLS RSA SHA256 2020 CA1
tls.subject: C=US, ST=California, L=San Francisco, O=Netlify, Inc, CN=*.netlify.app
tls.note: Wildcard certificate covers ALL netlify.app subdomains — attacker gets trusted TLS for free

crtsh.first_seen: N/A — subdomain uses Netlify wildcard cert (*.netlify.app); no individual cert issued
crtsh.note: crt.sh returns empty for this subdomain because Netlify uses a shared wildcard certificate (*.netlify.app) issued by DigiCert. Individual subdomain certificates are not logged in CT logs.

verdict.note: Not flagged as malicious by urlscan.io automated engines — demonstrates how free-tier scams evade detection

urlscan_data.key_findings: Roblox Premium-themed scam page hosted on Netlify free tier. Loads legitimate rbxcdn.com background image (premium_title_bg.jpg) to appear authentic. Uses Cloudflare Pages (zr-dqb.pages.dev) for additional assets. Loads suspicious JavaScript from CloudFront distributions (dfmpe7igjx4jo, d1y3y09sav47f5) and histawts.com ad/tracking network. Includes check.php tracking endpoint. Self-hosts fake testimonial images (sara1.png, samue.png). Not flagged by any urlscan.io engine despite clear scam indicators.

steps: Step 1 (box1): Victim sees 'Free Robux - Limited Time' banner with real Roblox Premium background image. Prompted to enter Roblox username in text input field.

Step 2 (box2 - 4.5s timer): After clicking 'Get Robux', box1 hides and a folding-cube CSS animation displays with text 'Searching for <username> ...' — a fake lookup that does nothing server-side. Runs for exactly 4500ms.

Step 3 (box3): After the timer, a Robux selection grid appears showing 4 tiers: 40,000 / 20,000 / 10,000 / 5,000 Robux — all priced at $0.00. Each tier has a Robux icon loaded from Cloudflare Pages (zr-dqb.pages.dev).
Step 4 (box2 again - 2.5s timer): Clicking any Robux amount triggers another loading animation with text 'Sending Robux to <username>...' for 2500ms — another fake delay.

Step 5 (box4): After the second timer, a message appears: 'Don't miss out on this chance...' with a 'Click Here' button that calls _WT() — a function defined by the external XF content locker JavaScript (not in the inline code).

Step 6 (XF content locker modal): The _WT() function triggers the hidden #xf_MODAL_CONTAINER injected by the CloudFront-hosted XF kit. This opens a modal overlay containing an iframe (#xfOFFERS) that loads a CPA offer wall / survey wall / app install page.

Step 7 (CPA completion): The victim must complete one or more 'human verification' offers (surveys, app installs, email submits) for the scam operator to earn CPA commission. No Robux is ever delivered.
scam_flow.username_usage: The username is captured from the input field and displayed back to the victim in the loading messages ('Searching for X', 'Sending Robux to X') purely for social engineering — creating the illusion of a personalized server-side operation. The username is NOT sent to any backend endpoint in the inline JavaScript. However, the externally-loaded XF content locker script (xfMAINJS) may access the DOM and exfiltrate it — the exact behavior depends on the obfuscated CloudFront JS.
scam_flow.data_sent_to: d1y3y09sav47f5.cloudfront.net via check.php (CPA tracking beacon with it=4507479&time=<timestamp>); offer wall completions route through the XF content locker iframe (#xfOFFERS) to the CPA network backend
scam_flow.final_redirect: XF content locker modal overlay with iframe-embedded CPA offer wall (surveys, app installs, email submits). The _WT() function triggers the modal — no direct URL redirect, the offers load inside the #xfOFFERS iframe within the page.
scam_flow.monetization_method: CPA (Cost Per Action) fraud via content locker. The XF kit's 'PrimeApps' campaign template presents offer walls inside an iframe modal. Scam operator earns commission ($0.50-$3.00 per completed action) when victims complete surveys, install apps, or submit personal information. The check.php endpoint tracks victim flow and credits the operator's account (it=4507479).
scam_flow.content_locker_kit: XF Content Locker (identified by 'xf' prefix on all injected DOM elements: xfMAINJS, xfGLOBALSTYLE, xfSPECIFICSTYLE, xfOFFERS, xf_MODAL_CONTAINER, xfMODALCONTENT, xfMODALHEADER, xfMODALBODY, xfMODALFOOTER, xfLEADCHECK, xfSettingsCSS)

external_resources.purpose: Background image for the hero banner — this is the REAL Roblox Premium subscription page background, hotlinked directly from Roblox's CDN to create visual authenticity
Robux currency icon used in the Robux amount selection grid (loaded 4 times, once per tier). Hosted on a randomly-generated Cloudflare Pages subdomain as a disposable asset host.
Roblox logo animation (webp) displayed in the navigation bar. Using Giphy as an image host avoids self-hosting brand assets and leverages Giphy's trusted domain reputation.

Stage-1 loader script for the XF content locker kit. Reads the PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc config object ({it:4507479, key:'86cfc'}) and dynamically injects the stage-2 main script, CSS files, check.php beacon, and the modal overlay DOM elements. The filename '9621def.js' appears to be a hash-based deployment artifact.

Stage-2 XF content locker main script (id='xfMAINJS'). The filename encodes the campaign parameters: random prefix 'hVLBFSu3YKQ', operator ID '4507479', key '86cfc', version '0'. Defines the _WT() function that triggers the offer wall modal, handles offer iframe loading, and manages the content locker UX flow.

CPA tracking beacon / lead validation endpoint (id='xfLEADCHECK'). Loaded as a <script> tag to execute server-side tracking. The 'it' parameter is the operator/campaign ID (4507479), 'time' is a Unix timestamp for deduplication. Counts unique visitors and validates them as real leads before serving offers.
Global CSS for the XF content locker modal overlay (id='xfGLOBALSTYLE'). Styles the modal container, backdrop, and iframe embed.

Campaign-specific CSS for the 'PrimeApps' content locker template (id='xfSPECIFICSTYLE', data-it='4507479'). The path '/public/clockers/PrimeApps/' reveals the kit variant name — 'clockers' likely refers to content lockers, 'PrimeApps' is the specific visual theme/template.

Visitor counting and analytics tracking. Account ID 2859602. Note the intentional capitalization 'histaWts' vs the real domain 'histats.com' — this may be a typo in the kit or an attempt to evade domain-based blocklists. The script returned 0 bytes to urlscan.io's crawler, suggesting bot detection or geo-fencing.
Web fonts (Kumbh Sans primarily used). Loads 6 font families though only Kumbh Sans is referenced in CSS — the extra fonts are likely copied from the phishing kit template.
Fake testimonial/social proof image #1 — likely a stock photo or AI-generated face used to simulate a real user named 'Sara' who received free Robux
Fake testimonial/social proof image #2 — likely a stock photo or AI-generated face used to simulate a real user named 'Samuel' who received free Robux

javascript_analysis.obfuscation_details: The inline JavaScript is NOT obfuscated — it is simple, readable vanilla JS. However, the externally-loaded XF content locker scripts from CloudFront are obfuscated: the stage-1 loader (9621def.js) uses a hash-based filename, and the stage-2 script (hVLBFSu3YKQ.4507479.86cfc.0.js) uses an encoded filename format. The config variable name 'PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc' is randomly generated to avoid pattern matching. The critical _WT() function is defined only in the external scripts, hiding the monetization mechanism from static analysis of the HTML source.
javascript_analysis.fake_progress_details: CSS-only folding cube animation (sk-foldCubeAngle keyframes, 2.4s infinite loop) displayed during two timed delays. No actual progress tracking — purely theatrical.
timer_details: setTimeout(showbox2, 4500) — 4.5 second fake 'searching for username' delay
setTimeout(showbox3, 4500) — runs in parallel to show Robux selection after delay
setTimeout(showbox4, 2500) — runs in parallel to show 'Click Here' CTA after delay

external_scripts.role: XF content locker stage-1 loader — reads config var PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc and dynamically injects all other XF resources
XF content locker stage-2 main script — defines _WT() function, manages modal/iframe offer wall, handles CPA offer flow
CPA lead validation/tracking beacon loaded as script tag

data_collection: Username input field (.username) — captured client-side and displayed in loading messages; may be read by XF external scripts
Histats hit tracking — browser fingerprint, referrer, page views sent to histats.com (account 2859602)
check.php beacon — records visitor with operator ID (it=4507479) and timestamp for CPA attribution
XF offer wall iframe — any data entered in the offer wall (email, phone, app installs) is collected by the CPA network, not directly by the scam page
javascript_analysis.notable_code: The inline JS uses a 4-box state machine: box1 (input) -> box2 (loading animation, reused twice) -> box3 (Robux selection) -> box4 (CTA button). The _WT() function on the final button is NOT defined anywhere in the inline script — it is injected by the external XF content locker JS from CloudFront. This separation means static HTML analysis misses the entire monetization layer. The PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc config object ({it:4507479, key:'86cfc'}) is the handshake between the static HTML and the dynamic content locker kit — 'it' is the operator/campaign ID and 'key' is an authentication token.

dom_injection_by_external_scripts.description: Comparing the static HTML source to the urlscan DOM snapshot reveals elements dynamically injected by the XF content locker JavaScript at runtime
injected_elements: <script id='xfMAINJS'> — stage-2 main JS from d1y3y09sav47f5.cloudfront.net
<style id='xfSettingsCSS'> — inline modal animation CSS (600ms transition)
<div id='xfMODALBODY'> with <iframe id='xfOFFERS'> — the actual CPA offer wall iframe

branding_elements: Page title set to 'Roblox' — direct brand impersonation
Roblox Premium background image hotlinked from images.rbxcdn.com (premium_title_bg.jpg)
Roblox logo loaded as animated GIF from Giphy in the nav bar
Robux currency icon from Cloudflare Pages (zr-dqb.pages.dev/robux-removebg-preview.png)
Nav bar with 'Discover', 'Marketplace', 'Robux' links mimicking real Roblox.com navigation
Hamburger menu icon (Unicode ☰) matching Roblox's mobile nav pattern
Color scheme (#dee1e3 nav, #f2f4f5 background, #393b3d text) closely matching Roblox's actual UI palette
trust_signals: HTTPS padlock from Netlify's wildcard certificate
'$0.00' pricing on all Robux tiers — implies the offers are completely free
Professional-looking UI with clean typography (Kumbh Sans font family)
Fake testimonial images (sara1.png, samue.png) as social proof
Description text copied from real Roblox: 'Robux allows you to purchase upgrades for your avatar or buy special abilities in experiences'
Multiple Google AdSense meta tags and Blogger profile links injected to appear as a legitimate monetized site to crawlers

fake_testimonials.note: Self-hosted on Netlify (no text/review content visible in HTML — the testimonial section div structure is incomplete/broken, suggesting the kit template was not fully customized)
Self-hosted on Netlify (same incomplete structure — filenames suggest intended fake personas)

urgency_language: 'Free Robux - Limited Time' — creates urgency and FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out)
'Don't miss out on this chance' — loss aversion framing
'Start now and dive into a world of unlimited possibilities' — action-oriented urgency
'Happy gaming!' — positive emotional manipulation suggesting the reward is imminent
social_engineering.target_demographic: Children and teenagers aged 8-16 who play Roblox and desire premium currency (Robux) but may lack the means to purchase it legitimately

roblox_specific.real_page_mimicked: Roblox Premium subscription page (roblox.com/premium/membership) — identified by the premium_title_bg.jpg background image, the Robux pricing grid layout, and the '$0.00' pricing mimicking the Premium tier display

real_roblox_assets_loaded.asset_type: Premium subscription page hero background image

features_referenced: Roblox Premium subscription (via the Premium background image and pricing grid format)
Robux virtual currency (the entire premise of the scam)
Avatar upgrades ('purchase upgrades for your avatar')
Roblox experiences/games ('buy special abilities in experiences')
Roblox username system (the input field prompt)
roblox_specific.note: The Robux amounts use European number formatting (dots as thousands separators: '40.000') rather than the American format Roblox uses ('40,000'), suggesting the scam operator may be European. Real Roblox Premium tiers offer 450/1,000/2,200 Robux per month — the amounts shown (5,000-40,000) are wildly inflated to maximize the lure's appeal.

notable_markers: Config variable with randomized name 'PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc' containing {it:<operator_id>, key:<auth_key>}

All injected DOM elements use 'xf' prefix: xfMAINJS, xfGLOBALSTYLE, xfSPECIFICSTYLE, xfSettingsCSS, xfLEADCHECK, xf_MODAL_CONTAINER, xf_MODAL, xfMODALCONTENT, xfMODALHEADER, xfMODALTITLE, xfMODALBODY, xfOFFERS, xfMODALFOOTER, xfMODALFOOTERTEXT
Two-stage loader architecture: stage-1 on separate CloudFront distribution reads config and bootstraps stage-2
check.php beacon with 'it' (operator ID) and 'time' (timestamp) parameters for lead tracking
Path '/public/clockers/' — 'clockers' is the kit's internal term for content lockers
CSS animation settings injected via <style id='xfSettingsCSS'> with configurable animation-duration (600ms)
Iframe-based offer wall in #xfOFFERS with modal overlay pattern
13 Blogger profile links with google-adsense-platform-account metadata — SEO/reputation padding likely from the kit template, not the operator

two_cloudfront_distributions.distribution_2: d1y3y09sav47f5.cloudfront.net — hosts stage-2 scripts, CSS, tracking endpoints, and offer wall resources
two_cloudfront_distributions.note: Using two separate CloudFront distributions provides resilience: if one is taken down, the other can be repointed. The stage-1 loader is kept minimal so it can be easily redeployed on a new distribution.

blogger_seo_spam.description: The HTML <head> contains 13 unique Blogger profile links (rel='me') and repeated google-adsense-platform-account metadata for 'ca-host-pub-1556223355139109'. This is NOT related to the scam content itself — it is SEO manipulation / link farming, likely injected by the phishing kit template to boost the page's perceived legitimacy to search engine crawlers.

security_concepts: Content locker monetization: The XF kit is a 'content locker' — it gates desired content (fake Robux) behind CPA offer completion. The operator earns $0.50-$3.00 per completed action (survey, app install, email submit). This is CPA fraud because the locked content does not exist.

Two-stage JavaScript loading: The kit uses a minimal stage-1 loader on one CloudFront distribution that reads a page-embedded config object and dynamically loads the full stage-2 kit from a second CloudFront distribution. This architecture provides resilience (swap distributions independently), obfuscation (stage-1 appears benign), and configurability (one loader supports many campaigns via config vars).

DOM injection for evasion: The entire monetization apparatus (modal, iframe, CSS, tracking) is injected at runtime by external JavaScript. Static HTML analysis (curl, wget, basic crawlers) sees only an innocent-looking Roblox fan page. Only a JS-capable renderer (browser, urlscan.io DOM capture) reveals the content locker infrastructure.

Cross-origin asset distribution: By splitting assets across 5+ domains (Netlify, two CloudFront distributions, Cloudflare Pages, Giphy, rbxcdn.com), the kit makes it nearly impossible to block based on any single domain and forces multi-provider takedown coordination.

Operator-specific tracking: The 'it' parameter (4507479) serves as the operator's unique ID in the CPA network, enabling revenue attribution. The 'key' (86cfc) is an authentication token preventing unauthorized use of the operator's campaign slot.

Bot evasion: The histawts.com script returned 0 bytes to urlscan.io's headless browser, suggesting active bot detection. Content lockers commonly fingerprint visitors and refuse to serve offers to known bots/scanners to avoid CPA network penalties for fake impressions.
talking_points: Full scam funnel traced: Username input (social engineering hook) -> fake 4.5s 'searching' animation -> Robux tier selection -> fake 2.5s 'sending' animation -> _WT() triggers XF content locker modal -> iframe loads CPA offer wall -> victim completes surveys/installs for operator revenue -> no Robux ever delivered

The _WT() function is the critical pivot point: it exists ONLY in the external CloudFront JS, creating a clean separation between the 'innocent' HTML (which could pass automated scanning) and the monetization layer (which requires JavaScript execution to detect)

XF content locker kit identification: The 'xf' prefix on 15+ injected DOM element IDs, the '/public/clockers/' path, the 'PrimeApps' campaign template, the two-CloudFront-distribution architecture, and the check.php tracking beacon collectively identify this as the XF content locker kit — a known CPA fraud toolkit

The Blogger profile links and AdSense metadata (13 profiles, publisher ID ca-host-pub-1556223355139109) are SEO manipulation — they make the page appear to be a legitimate Blogger-hosted site to search engine crawlers, potentially improving its ranking for 'free Robux' searches
European number formatting on Robux amounts (40.000 vs 40,000) is an operational security failure — it reveals the likely geographic origin of the scam operator

The hardcoded default text 'searching for amjad ...' in the HTML (visible in both source and DOM) suggests 'amjad' is likely the developer's test username or real name — another OPSEC failure that could aid attribution

Defense-in-depth observation: No single security layer would have caught this — it evaded urlscan ML scoring, has no malicious signatures in the static HTML, uses legitimate CDN infrastructure, and has a valid TLS certificate. Detection requires behavioral analysis of the full JavaScript execution chain.
notable_findings: OPSEC leak: The default useroutput text 'searching for amjad ...' is hardcoded in the HTML, suggesting the kit developer or operator's name/alias is 'amjad'
The XF content locker injects exactly 12 new DOM elements at runtime, none of which appear in the static HTML source — this is a textbook example of dynamic payload delivery for evasion
The check.php endpoint timestamp (1770272688538) corresponds to approximately 2026-02-05T18:04:48Z, aligning with the urlscan scan date and confirming this is a live, active CPA tracking beacon
The CSS animation for the modal (600ms, configured via xfSettingsCSS) is deliberately tuned — fast enough to feel responsive, slow enough to look like a 'real' verification process loading
The kit's config variable name 'PxZvh_IFY_qQEzlc' is randomly generated per deployment, preventing signature-based detection of the config handshake between HTML and the external loader
The scam page has zero cookies — all tracking is done via the external check.php beacon and Histats, keeping the Netlify-hosted page stateless and harder to fingerprint

The incomplete testimonial section (empty div structures around sara1.png/samue.png with no review text) suggests the operator deployed a partially-configured kit template — the testimonial text was never filled in, reducing the social engineering effectiveness but not enough to prevent the scam from operating for 204+ days

security_concepts: Free-tier platform abuse: Netlify provides automatic TLS (via shared wildcard cert), global CDN, and static hosting at zero cost — the attacker has zero infrastructure investment
Wildcard TLS certificates: Netlify's *.netlify.app DigiCert wildcard cert gives every subdomain a green padlock, making phishing sites appear 'secure' to victims
Domain reputation parasitism: rbux4aall.netlify.app inherits netlify.app's domain reputation, making it harder for URL filters to block without risking false positives on legitimate Netlify sites
Trust exploitation via legitimate CDN assets: Loading the real Roblox Premium background image from images.rbxcdn.com creates visual authenticity without hosting the asset

Cross-platform asset hosting: Assets split across Netlify, Cloudflare Pages (zr-dqb.pages.dev), CloudFront distributions, and Giphy — all free-tier services — making takedown require contacting multiple providers
CT log evasion: Because Netlify uses a shared wildcard certificate, individual phishing subdomains do not appear in Certificate Transparency logs, eliminating a major detection signal
HSTS preloading: Netlify's HSTS with preload means even the HTTP->HTTPS redirect is handled by the browser internally (307 Internal Redirect), adding another layer of apparent security
talking_points: Domain naming analysis: 'rbux4aall' decodes to 'Robux for all' — a social engineering lure specifically targeting children/young Roblox players who want free premium currency
Detection gap: urlscan.io's ML engine scored this at -82 (not malicious) and zero community votes flagged it — demonstrating how simple static scam pages evade automated detection
Fake social proof: Self-hosted images sara1.png and samue.png are likely fabricated user testimonials designed to build trust, a classic scam pattern

Suspicious JavaScript pipeline: The site loads JS from dfmpe7igjx4jo.cloudfront.net and d1y3y09sav47f5.cloudfront.net (randomized CloudFront distributions), plus histawts.com (known ad/tracking domain) — suggesting CPA/affiliate fraud or credential harvesting backend

check.php tracking endpoint: The call to d1y3y09sav47f5.cloudfront.net/public/external/check.php with 'it' and 'time' parameters indicates victim tracking/counting infrastructure, common in CPA (Cost Per Action) scam networks

Reporting to Netlify: Submit abuse report at https://www.netlify.com/abuse/ with the domain, urlscan screenshot, and description of the scam. Netlify typically responds to abuse reports within 24-48 hours for clear ToS violations
The page title is simply 'Roblox' — impersonating Roblox Corporation (brand abuse), which strengthens a DMCA/trademark takedown request

Multi-platform takedown complexity: Effective remediation requires reports to Netlify (main site), Cloudflare (zr-dqb.pages.dev image host), AWS/CloudFront (JS and tracking infrastructure), and potentially Roblox Corporation (brand abuse/rbxcdn.com asset misuse)
notable_findings: LIVE AND SERVING: The site returned HTTP 200 with 15,012 bytes of content as of 2026-02-07, confirming it is still active and operational
Domain age is 204 days (~6.8 months) — this scam has persisted for months without being taken down, indicating a detection/reporting gap
Two A records (13.52.188.95, 52.52.192.191) both in AWS us-west-1 (San Jose, CA) — standard Netlify load-balanced infrastructure
Two AAAA records (2600:1f1c:446:4900::258, 2600:1f1c:446:4900::259) — IPv6 enabled via AWS

urlscan.io resolved the site to a DIFFERENT IP (35.157.26.135 in eu-central-1 Frankfurt) vs our dig results (us-west-1 San Jose) — Netlify CDN serves from geographically nearest PoP, confirming global CDN distribution
No TXT records, no SPF/DKIM — not configured for email (pure web-based scam)
Netlify Edge cache hit indicates the content is being served from CDN edge cache, not origin — meaning fast delivery worldwide
histawts.com script (s10.histawts.com/js15_as.js) returned 0 bytes in urlscan — likely geo-fenced or bot-detecting, suggesting the scam operators are using evasive ad/tracking infrastructure

The rbxcdn.com asset used is specifically the Roblox Premium title background — the scam theme is a fake 'Roblox Premium' generator, one of the most effective lures for the target demographic (children aged 8-16)
Cloudflare Pages subdomain 'zr-dqb' appears randomly generated — likely a disposable asset host that can be quickly replaced if taken down
